I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This regional technical assistance (RETA) will help the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
and its developing member countries better institutionalize antitrafficking1 and safe migration 
concerns  into  subregional  cooperation  and  integration  initiatives.  The  focus  will  be  on  the 
Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) and South Asia.2 The RETA, which will strengthen ADB’s 
partnerships with regional institutions within and across subregions, is consistent with ADB’s 
Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Strategy 3  and  incorporates  feedback  from  ADB’s 
developing member countries. During the February 2008 Fact-Finding Mission, discussions with 
key regional partners and governments confirmed the relevance of the proposed activities, 
implementation  arrangements,  cost  estimates,  and  terms  of  reference.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  During the last decade accelerated globalization and migration have increased global 
attention  on  human  trafficking. 5  Targeted  projects  in  source  areas,  transit  points,  and 
destinations provided awareness raising campaigns; community-based monitoring; livelihood 
development,  and  empowerment  of  women  and  girls;  legal  protection  and  advice  for 
prosecution,  improvement  of  labor  standards  in  small  factories,  and  skills  training  for 
reintegration. Some have achieved notable success. Progress has been also made in clarifying 
concepts (e.g., definition of human trafficking, push and pull factors, links between trafficking 
and migration), consolidating research and good practice databases, increasing commitment by 
governments to combat the problem as reflected by the signing of international conventions, 
regional declarations, bilateral agreements, and country plans of actions; and recognizing the 
need for multidisciplinary and multistakeholder approaches.  
 
3.  The annual trafficking in persons report, published by the United States’ Department of 
State, has been instrumental in drawing worldwide attention to the need for urgent actions. 
Since 2001 the report has ranked countries according to their performance in addressing human 
trafficking; American bilateral and multilateral foreign assistance reflects this ranking.6 
 
4.  The issue of human trafficking is highly relevant to ADB’s regional cooperation agenda. 
First, evidence is growing of the links between improved rural–urban and regional connectivity, 
and increased vulnerability to human trafficking and unsafe migration, especially in the context

reduce individuals’ risks of being trafficked for exploitation. 
2   The selection of the two subregions is based on needs and gaps identified from ADB experience, the recognized 
roles of ADB on this topic, and consultations with ADB staff in charge of regional cooperation in key subregions. 
The RETA is in line with the regional cooperation strategies and programs for the GMS and South Asia. See 
ADB. 2004. Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program (2004–2008): Greater Mekong Subregion. Manila; and 
ADB. 2005. Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program (2006–2008): South Asia. Manila.  
3   ADB. 2006. Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy. Manila. 
4  The TA first appeared in  ADB Business Opportunities on 17 January 2008. Funding from the Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Fund under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility 
was approved on 10 September 2007. 
5   In Asia the key financiers of antitrafficking initiatives include the governments of the United States, United 
Kingdom, Norway, and Australia. They have channeled funds through the United Nations technical agencies, 
e.g., International Labour Organization, International Organization for Migration, United Nations Children’s Fund, 
United Nations Development Fund for Women, and more recently United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime; 
governments,  and  nongovernment  organizations.  The  private  sector  is  increasing  becoming  involved,  for 
example, Microsoft, Manpower, and GAP. 
6   The 2007 report is available at: http://www.state.gov/g/tip/rls/tiprpt/2007/.

2   
of poorly implemented development policies.7 As a leader in facilitating improved connectivity, 
ADB should ensure that governments provide necessary legal frameworks and law enforcement 
to make the mobility of people safe, especially for women and children. This requires the 
integration of trafficking and safe migration concerns into regional and cross-border corridors 
and  connectivity  planning.  Second,  as  a  regional  development  bank,  ADB  is  expected  to 
catalyze regional policy dialogue, partner with other regional institutions, and contribute to 
quality policy research on key regional public goods issues, including human trafficking and safe 
migration. ADB recognizes these two roles in its Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy.  
 
5.  To date, ADB support to antitrafficking and safe migration include three RETAs: one in 
South Asia (2001–2003),8 one in the GMS (2004–2007),9 and another in the GMS to integrate 
antitrafficking and safe migration messages with HIV/AIDS and nontraditional drug use among 
ethnic minority groups (2005–2007).10 In addition, ADB’s 18 transport loan projects since 2002 
have  included  sensitization  components  on  human  trafficking.  These  efforts  have  largely 
focused  on  regional  policy  dialogue;  regional,  country,  and  local  research;  community 
awareness raising and targeted communication program development; empowerment of women 
and girls; targeted poverty reduction; and community-based monitoring. 
 
6.  Through these ADB has gained substantial institutional knowledge on (i) key issues, 
bottlenecks, and stakeholders in the GMS and South Asia; (ii) ways to develop and implement 
project components to reduce vulnerability to human trafficking and unsafe migration; and  
(iii) ways, at the project level, to engage line ministries (transport sector, in particular) that do not 
normally deal with trafficking or migration issues. Through this process, ADB has refined its 
unique role in addressing trafficking and safe migration issues.  
 
7.  ADB has successfully facilitated regional policy dialogue to develop regional institutional 
frameworks.  In  the  GMS,  ADB  contributed  to  the  formulation  and  implementation  of  the 
memorandum  of  understanding  of  the  Coordinated  Mekong  Ministerial  Initiative  against 
Trafficking (COMMIT) by providing funding support to the United Nations Inter-Agency Project 
on Human Trafficking in the Greater Mekong Sub-Region (UNIAP), a secretariat for COMMIT. In 
South Asia, key government decision-makers and leading nongovernment organizations (NGOs) 
from Bangladesh, India, and Nepal came together to discuss a range of bilateral and regional 
issues, including the 2002 Convention on Preventing and Combating Trafficking in Women and 
Children for Prostitution by the South Asia Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC).  
 
8.  However,  major  gaps  still  exist  in  mainstreaming  and  integrating  these  efforts  into  
(i) ADB-assisted subregional cooperation and economic integration, such as the GMS and the 
South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC); and (ii) subregional policy dialogue. 
Given  their  cross-cutting  nature,  human  trafficking  and  safe  migration  issues  need  to  be 
addressed through and side-by-side with such economic sectors as transport, tourism, and 
trade, among others. At the same time, ADB is expected to play a stronger role in facilitating

9.  The  GMS  leads  other  subregional  initiatives  in  integrating  antitrafficking  and  safe 
migration concerns. The GMS Working Group on Human Resource Development (WGHRD) 
considers cross-cutting social dimensions, including human trafficking and safe labor migration. 
However, its approach to these issues is still ad hoc; it does not have systematic links with 
COMMIT and its subregional plan of action (SPA). The group’s capacity to work with other GMS 
thematic working groups, such as transport, tourism, and trade, needs to be strengthened to 
address trafficking and safe migration concerns, building upon pilot interventions under the 
recently  completed  RETA  6190  (footnote  9).  An  informal  group  on  social  development 
established during WGHRD’s eighth meeting in May 2007 offers an opportunity. An ongoing 
RETA11 is facilitating a consultative process to develop a GMS–WGHRD strategic framework. 
Further technical and secretariat assistance is needed for the social development subgroup to 
develop and implement a more detailed strategic action framework specific to their concerns, 
while establishing its membership, roles, and accountability mechanism. The group should be 
assisted to take a proactive role in interacting with other thematic working groups through joint 
training and cross-border planning.  
 
10.  SASEC  does  not  have  a  focal  working  group  on  human  development  or  social 
development that corresponds to WGHRD in the GMS. Even in the few cases where ADB has 
provided support to develop a component on trafficking sensitization and community monitoring 
with cross-border projects under SASEC, these activities were carried out in isolation from any 
national or regional action plans on combating human trafficking. With no focal point on cross-
border social issues, SASEC operations have missed opportunities to promote safe and regular 
migration through such sectors as transport, trade and customs, and possibly regional tourism. 
As SASEC moves from its project focus to cross-border agreements and interventions in the 
medium  term,  trafficking  and  safe  migration  concerns  must  be  integrated  into  any  overall 
framework. Global and regional good practices should be introduced to find ways to systematize 
and institutionalize these concerns into cross-border and connectivity planning under SASEC.  
 
11.  Regional policy dialogue support remains important. Now recognized as an important 
regional participant, ADB’s continuing support to the COMMIT process and COMMIT SPA 
2008–2010 will be crucial to sustain ongoing regional policy dialogue on antitrafficking and safe 
migration and to strengthen the linkage between the GMS WGHRD and COMMIT.  
 
12.  In South Asia, numerous bilateral initiatives and NGO regional networks are in place, but 
no single comprehensive regionwide platform equivalent to COMMIT in the GMS countries is in 
place for government and nongovernment sectors. The 2002 SAARC convention remains the 
only regional platform but with a limited scope. Its effective implementation has been hampered 
by its limited legal provisions (e.g., form of exploitation is limited to prostitution) and weak 
institutional structure (e.g., no accountability required for signing countries). The United Nations 
Development  Fund  for  Women  and  United  Nations  Children’s  Fund,  in  collaboration  with 
governments and NGOs, have facilitated advocating for some changes in the convention. But 
more support for regionwide discussions is needed, especially for the SAARC summit in Sri 
Lanka in 2009.  
 
                                                 
11   ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Human Resource Development Cooperation in the Greater 
Mekong Subregion. Manila (RETA 6413, for $200,000).

4   
13.  While challenges and solutions are country and subregion specific, key stakeholders 
consider  exchanges  between  countries  and  subregions  to  be  useful.  Cross-country  and 
subregional training is often instrumental in stimulating new ideas and changes in terms of 
operating modalities and project design.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The expected impact of the RETA is enhanced integration of concerns about human 
trafficking and safe migration of women and children into ADB-assisted subregional cooperation 
and integration strategies and interventions. The two distinct but interrelated outcomes will be 
(i) enhanced mainstreaming of human trafficking and safe migration concerns within the GMS 
and SASEC, and (ii) enhanced regional policy dialogue and partnerships on these topics in the 
GMS and South Asia.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
  1.   GMS (Part A)  
 
15.  Output 1: Capacity Development of WGHRD’s Social Development Subgroup. The 
RETA will facilitate a consultative process for developing a GMS strategy on human trafficking 
and safe migration within the overall WGHRD strategic framework (to be developed under 
ongoing RETA 6413 [footnote 11]) and the COMMIT SPA, and help the social development 
subgroup implement it. It will provide technical and secretariat assistance to formalize the terms 
of reference and strengthen the capacity of the newly formulated social development subgroup 
under the GMS–WGHRD. The RETA will help the social development subgroup take an active 
role  in  engaging  other  relevant  GMS  thematic  working  groups  (e.g.,  transport,  trade,  and 
tourism) and provide necessary inputs to the sector-specific training modules and community-
based monitoring and referral system provided by output 2.  
 
16.  Output 2:  Support to COMMIT. To continue to support the COMMIT process and  
SPA 2008–2010, the RETA will partner with UNIAP as a secretariat for COMMIT. Building upon 
the successful experiences of the recently completed RETA 6190 (footnote 9), the proposed 
RETA will support two suboutputs as part of the COMMIT SPA 2008–2010: (i) regional and local 
training targeted at more than 150 senior and technical government officials and NGO staff, 
using proven interactive training modules; and special training modules catering to the needs of 
key  GMS  economic  sectors;  and  (ii)  community-based  monitoring  and  referral  systems 
implemented in at least two locations, along with ADB-assisted GMS regional projects that 
would accelerate cross-border mobility.  
 
2.   South Asia (Part B) 
 
17.   Output 3: Raising Awareness of Human Trafficking Concerns in SASEC. The RETA 
will review the current knowledge, practices, and opportunities in relevant SASEC economic 
sectors to make the cross-border and connectivity planning and projects sensitive to the risks of 
human trafficking and unsafe migration. In consultation with key stakeholders, it will provide a 
roadmap with recommendations for institutionalizing these concerns into SASEC’s key sector 
strategies and work programs such as training and cross-border investments. Advisory services 
will be provided for key sector working groups for developing strategies and projects addressing 
trafficking and safe migration concerns.

5
18.  Output 4: Policy Dialogue on the SAARC Convention. The RETA will partner with the 
International Organization for Migration (IOM) South Asia to prepare a discussion paper on 
improvements to the SAARC Convention and its operating framework. A small regional working 
group will be established to refine the paper and recommendations, which will be discussed 
through regional consultative workshops for possible consideration at the 2009 SAARC summit.  
 
  3.  Subregion (Part C) 
 
19.  Output 5:  Subregional Exchange. The RETA will provide at least three exchange 
programs across subregions, involving the GMS, South Asia, Central Asia and Caucasus,  
Southeast Asia,  and  the  Pacific. To  achieve  synergies and  leverage  limited  resources,  all 
training and exchange programs under the RETA will utilize those offered by the International 
Labour Organization and other partners. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The total cost of the RETA is estimated at $1,000,000 (Appendix 2). The RETA will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund under the Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility established and administered by 
ADB. UNIAP and IOM will provide in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  The RETA will be implemented over 24 months (June 2008–May 2010). In-country 
activities will commence after a letter of no-objection is received from the respective government. 
ADB through the Gender, Social Development, and Civil Society Division of the Regional and 
Sustainable Development Department (RSGS) will be the Executing Agency. Throughout the 
RETA, RSGS will consult closely with and be guided by the Southeast Asia and South Asia 
regional departments and resident missions. In the GMS and SASEC, a government focal 
person should be appointed from each of the key thematic working groups to formulate a RETA 
peer review committee, which will provide feedback on consultant inputs. RETA progress and 
outputs will be posted and updated regularly on ADB’s social development website with links to 
the GMS and SASEC websites.  
 
22.  UNIAP will be the Implementing Agency for output 2 and IOM South Asia for output 4 to 
undertake the RETA consulting services, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  form  time  to  time),  based  on  the  single-source  selection 
procedure. ADB will directly engage two international consultants (total of 9 person-months) and 
two national consultants (total of 30 person-months) on an individual basis, in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. They should have knowledge and experience on 
the interface between ADB’s key economic sectors and human trafficking and migration. Outline 
terms of reference of partner agencies and consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 to be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Fund  under  the  Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility for Integrating Human Trafficking 
and Safe Migration Concerns for Women and Children into Regional Cooperation, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

1.  United  Nations  Inter-Agency  Project  on  Human  Trafficking  in  the  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion (UNIAP) was established in 2000 as a coordinating body of various United Nations 
agencies working on combating human trafficking and promoting safe migration in the six 
Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) countries. It serves as a secretariat to the Coordinated 
Mekong  Ministerial  Initiative  against  Trafficking  (COMMIT)  and  successfully  facilitated  the 
signing of regional memorandum of understanding by all six participating countries in 2005, and 
assisted  COMMIT  in  preparing  and  implementing  the  comprehensive  subregional  plans  of 
actions (SPA) 2005–2007 and 2008–2010. It has a regional office in Bangkok, supported by six 
country  offices,  and  partners  with  a  range  of  regional  institutions  and  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs). The single-source selection is justified given UNIAP’s unique position 
and  capacity  to  deliver  quality  products  on  time  demonstrated  by  its  work  with  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) regional technical assistance (RETA) for Preventing the Trafficking of 
Women and Children and Promoting Safe Migration in the Greater Mekong Subregion (RETA 
6190).1 
2.  UNIAP will have overall responsibility for the implementation of output 2 (support to 
COMMIT SPA) with ADB guidance and in close coordination with the output 1 consultants. 
UNIAP will be engaged for 24 months (June 2008–May 2010).  
3.  Regional and Local Training. Tasks include the following:  
(i)  Based on the priorities identified by the COMMIT subregional plan of action (SPA) 
2008–2010 and experience to date, conduct needs assessments and prepare 
training programs, target groups and numbers, schedules, and detailed budget of 
regional and local training on human trafficking and safe migration issues. 
(ii)  Explore ways to minimize training costs by maximizing partnerships with other 
agencies  and  institutions  (e.g.,  government  and  industry  employer  training 
organized by International Labour Organization on labor protection). 
(iii)  In close consultation with output 1 consultants, develop sensitization training 
modules  catering  to  the  specific  needs  of  GMS  working  groups  on  human 
resource  development,  transport,  trade,  tourism,  and  other  relevant  groups. 
Ensure that outputs produced by RETA 6190 and RETA 61712 are utilized for 
this purpose.  
(iv)  Upon  ADB  approval  of  the  training  plan,  conduct  or  supervise  all  training 
activities supported by the RETA, and document proceedings, accomplishments, 
and key lessons.

Migration in the Greater Mekong Subregion. Manila (RETA 6190).  
2   ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance for Reviewing Poverty Impact of Regional Economic Integration in the Greater 
Mekong Subregion. Manila (RETA 6171).

4.  Community-Based Monitoring and Referral. UNIAP’s tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  In close consultation with output 1 consultants, identify at least two locations 
along with ADB’s GMS interventions where community-based monitoring and 
referral systems would have the most demonstrable impacts.  
(ii)  Conduct  field  assessments,  collect  baseline  data;  and  develop  specific 
interventions, schedules, cost estimates, implementation arrangements, and a 
rapid method to assess quick impacts of community-based monitoring/referral 
interventions. In doing so, clarify the roles of different stakeholders including local 
governments, nongovernment and/or community-based organizations, and key 
ministries.  
(iii)  Conduct at least two sets of community-based monitoring and referral activities. 
(iv)  Develop  and  circulate  knowledge  dissemination  materials  based  on  the 
experience.  
5.  In  addition  to  required  day-to-day  communication,  UNIAP  will  provide  the  following 
reports to ADB:  
 
(i)  inception report with a detailed work plan (month 1); 
(ii)  semiannual financial and progress reports (by the end of months 6, 12, and 18)  
(iii)  midterm report (by end of month 12); 
(iv)  UNIAP  SIREN  reports  and  case  studies  as  appropriate,  particularly  from 
community-based monitoring (as appropriate); and 
(v)  final report (by end of month 24). 
 
B.  International Organization for Migration South Asia Regional Office  
6.  The International Organization for Migration (IOM) South Asia Regional Office in Dhaka 
was established in 1998, specializing in protecting the rights and improving the welfare of 
migrants,  reducing  trafficking,  and  any  other  issues  related  to  in-country  and  cross-border 
migration. The office covers six South Asian countries (Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, 
Nepal,  and  Sri  Lanka)  and  provides  such  services  as  research,  legal  advice,  technical 
assistance, project implementation, and regional policy dialogue. It has strong linkages with 
partner governments and regional and local nongovernmental organizations. The single-source 
selection is justified because of IOM South Asia’s unique regional capacity, expertise in human 
trafficking and safe migration issues, extensive networks, and the intellectual and practical 
leadership demonstrated in the two previous ADB technical assistance projects (RETA 59483 
and Technical Assistance 4085-BAN4).  
7.  IOM South Asia will have overall responsibility for implementation of output 4 (policy 
dialogue on South Asia Association for Regional Cooperation [SAARC] Convention) under the 
guidance of ADB and in close coordination with the output 2 international consultant.  
8.  IOM South Asia will be engaged under the RETA for 14 months (June 2008–August 
2009). The tasks of IOM South Asia will include the following: 
(i)  Establish  an  informal  regional  working  group  on  revisiting  the  SAARC 
Convention on Preventing and Combating Trafficking in Women and Children for 
                                                 
3   ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance for Combating Trafficking of Women and Children in South Asia. Manila (RETA

4   ADB. 2003. Preparing the Social Protection for Disadvantaged Women and Children. Manila.

Prostitution in 2002 and its operating and accountability mechanisms. Ensure the 
participation of partners and individuals that have been instrumental in earlier 
SAARC Convention preparation and improvement, such as the United Nations 
Development Fund for Women and United Nations Children’s Fund. 
(ii)  With technical inputs from the regional working group, draft a paper identifying 
gaps and methods to improve the SAARC Convention. 
(iii)  Conduct national and regional meetings to refine the recommendations, while 
strategically involving key individuals who could influence SAARC decisions. 
(iv)  Advocate for an opportunity for discussion of the key recommendations at the 
2009 SAARC summit in Sri Lanka.  
(v)  Review a range of past or ongoing South Asian regional forums on human 
trafficking and safe migration issues outside of SAARC (e.g., Action Against 
Trafficking  and  Sexual  Exploitation  of  Children,  South  Asia  Regional 
Initiative/Equity Support Program, government’s network, if any), and identify 
ways to improve communications and knowledge networking, and possible roles 
for ADB and IOM.  
 
9.  In addition to required day-to-day communication, IOM will provide the following reports 
to ADB according to the following schedules:  
(i)  inception report including work plan (month 1); 
(ii)  quarterly financial and progress reports (by end of months 3, 6, and 9); 
(iii)  a draft strategic paper reviewing the SAARC Convention Against Trafficking of 
Women and Children 2002 and its implementation and key recommendations (by 
month 6); 
(iv)  action plans for implementing the SAARC Convention from five countries for 
transmission to member governments (month 7); 
(v)  proceedings  of  country  and  regional  discussions  (within  1  month  from  the 
meeting); 
(vi)  a position paper on follow-up of the SAARC summit 2009 (month 12); and  
(vii)  final report (by end of month 12). 
 
C.  International Consultants (9 person-months) 
10.  ADB will recruit two international consultants on an individual basis. Each consultant will 
have a postgraduate degree in relevant social sciences and substantial experience in combating 
human trafficking, safe migration, labor mobility, social dimensions of regional cooperation, 
gender  and  development,  and  other  relevant  fields.  He/she  will  have  extensive  regional 
experience  in  capacity  development  of  institutions,  preferably  regional  institutions;  proven 
research and writing skills; and procedural familiarity with ADB or other multilateral development 
organizations.  The  consultants  will  report  to  ADB,  the  GMS,  and  South  Asia  Subregional 
Economic Cooperation (SASEC). 
11.  Support to the GMS Working Group on Human Resource Development (WGHRD) 
(3 person-months, intermittent). The tasks of the consultant will include the following: 
(i)  In close cooperation and coordination with RETA 6413,5 prepare and manage the 
overall work plan, budget, and implementation arrangements for output 1.  
                                                 
5   ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Human Resource Development Cooperation in the Greater 
Mekong Subregion. Manila (RETA 6413).

(ii)  Assist ADB in identifying a suitable national consultant and supervise his/her 
work. 
(iii)  Review key research, capacity building, and project work on human trafficking 
and unsafe migration, violation of migrant workers’ rights, HIV/AIDS, and other 
vulnerabilities related to cross-border connectivity, regional economic integration, 
and globalization that have been carried out with ADB assistance in the GMS 
(e.g., RETA 6190 (footnote 1), RETA 62476, and RETA 61717), those carried out 
by other agencies in the GMS (which not only includes human trafficking and 
safe migration work and also the labor migration project being carried out by the 
World Bank) and outside of the subregion. Identify key lessons. 
(iv)  Work closely with the consultants of RETA 6413 (footnote 5) to understand key 
discussions and decisions made during the consultative processes to formulate 
the social development subgroup’s strategic framework under the GMS WGHRD 
framework.  
(v)  Launch a series of consultations to prepare and agree on (a) a GMS strategy on  
human  trafficking  and  safe  migration  for  implementation  by  the  social 
development subgroup; and (b) terms of reference and membership for the social 
development subgroup and key GMS sector working groups on human trafficking 
and safe labor migration work in implementing such a strategy. This should 
involve clarifying the roles of central ministries and local governments.  
(vi)  Regularly provide inputs to and assist communication of UNIAP to the GMS 
working  groups  on  training  and  community-based  monitoring  and  referral 
systems.  
(vii)  Supervise and technically assist the national consultant in providing continuing 
advisory and secretariat functions to the social development subgroup and GMS 
sector working groups on matters related to human trafficking and labor migration.  
 
12.  Support to SASEC (6 person-months, intermittent). The tasks of the consultant will 
include the following: 
(i)  Prepare  and  manage  the  overall  work  plan,  budget,  and  implementation 
arrangements for output 3.  
(ii)  Assist ADB in identifying a suitable national consultant and supervise his/her 
work. 
(iii)  Review key project documents and experiences of past or ongoing interventions 
related  to  antitrafficking  and  safe  migration  initiatives  in  SASEC-assisted 
operations.  Collect  international  and  regional  good  practices  and  available 
resources (e.g., training manuals, information, education, and communication 
materials),  in  particular  from  the  GMS,  in  addressing  concerns  of  human 
trafficking, unsafe migration, violation of migrant workers’ rights, HIV/AIDS, and 
other vulnerabilities related to regional economic integration and cross-border 
connectivity  in  these  sector  contexts.  Review  existing  work  programs  and 
strategic documents of key sector working groups of SASEC (e.g., transport and 
communication,  trade  and  customs,  tourism)  and  identify  entry  points.  After 
consultations with key SASEC and regional stakeholders, recommend how to 
advance  awareness  and  provide  interventions  in  a  more  systematic  way. 
Synthesize all these into a discussion paper.

(iv)  Launch a series of consultations using the discussion paper. Based on the inputs 
from consultations, finalize the discussion paper.  
(v)  Provide  operating  support  and  training  to  key  individuals  in  SASEC  sector 
working  groups  to  raise  awareness  of  the  need  for  integration  of  human 
trafficking  and  safe  migration  concerns  into  cross-border  and  economic 
integration planning. Ensure that a training module on safe mobility is regularized 
into training programs of each sector working group.  
(vi)  Ensure that the finalized discussion paper recommendations are integrated into 
future cross-border and regional economic integration strategic and investment 
planning documents by regularly communicating with the SASEC RETA working 
group members and the SASEC secretariat.  
(vii)  Engage in regular dialogue with key development partners and implementing 
organizations working on human trafficking and safe migration in South Asia. 
Assess ways to revive the South Asia Regional Initiative/Equity Support Program 
as  a  comprehensive  knowledge  management  program  and  make 
recommendations for any follow-up (including cost estimates and implementation 
arrangements).  
 
D.  National Consultants (30 person-months) 
13.  Two national consultants (one in the GMS for 12 person-months and another in South 
Asia for 18 person-months) will be recruited on an individual basis. The key tasks of each 
consultant will include the following:  
(i)  Assist the international consultant by collecting data and materials, coordinating 
meetings and discussions, identifying key resource persons, and providing other 
support. 
(ii)  Under the guidance of the international consultants, review and analyze the data 
collected and draft background reports. 
(iii)  As a help desk, provide analytical and technical inputs on available resources, 
NGOs, national action plans, and good practices related to human trafficking and 
labor issues to GMS WGHRD and SASEC. 
(iv)  Perform  any  other  relevant  tasks  as  agreed  with  ADB  and  the  international 
consultants.
